title: Persistent Homology of Music Network with Three Different Distances
author: Eunwoo Heo (Pohang University of Science & Technology), Byeongchan Choi (Pohang University of Science & Technology), Myung Ock Kim (Korea Institute for Advanced Study), Mai Lan Tran (Pohang University of Science & Technology), Jae-Hun Jung (Pohang University of Science & Technology), ...
relevance_why: The paper applies persistent homology to music graph networks, which could offer insights for Haohe Liu's work on audio-related tasks that comprise graph representations.
background: The study analyzes music data represented as graphs and uses persistent homology methods to uncover topological structures with different distance measures.
contribution: This paper introduces three distinct distance definitions for music graph networks to analyze their impact on persistent homology, revealing systematic relationships in music data.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in music analysis applied persistent homology but did not explore various distance definitions or their effects on topological insights.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work systematically studies the impact of distance definitions on persistent homology, establishing clear inclusion relations among graphs.

key_innovation: Demonstrates how changing distance definitions based on graph pathways affects the topological insights derived from music data.
real_world_impact: Enhances understanding of the structure of music data, potentially aiding in AI music composition and analysis. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The effect of non-metric behavior of certain distance definitions on the analysis is not fully explored.

new_terms.persistent homology: **Persistent homology** is a method in topological data analysis that studies the changing topology of data across various scales, identifying features that persist over different distance thresholds.
new_terms.Vietoris-Rips complex: **Vietoris-Rips complex** is a construction from a point cloud that captures relationships between points based on a defined distance, facilitating the analysis of topological features.
